text: I have lived in Boquete the past two years (long after this happened) and one key to this, I believe, is the nature of the seasons in the area. From December through March, the afternoons are sunny and windy. From May through October, it is normally bright and sunny in the mornings but becomes rainy by 3 pm. Sometimes the storms are immense downpours that turn trails into streams. April is a month where the weather transitions from dry to rainy so there are sudden downpours on some days and no rain on others. I tend to believe that one of the two ladies was injured and both tried to call for help but there was no cell service in the area. They may have become disoriented by the fact that they could have crossed the continental divide so trekking downhill actually led them further from home, not closer. Neither of the girls were serious hikers, from what I have been told, and the trails in Panama can be rocky and treacherous, particularly in heavy rains. One or two wrong decisions may have sealed their doom.

text:
I'm Panamanian and remember this clearly, specially because I was studying my Bachelor in Tourism at the time. I rarely watch the news in my country but when I found out about this I was glued to the tv for any update.
This is really very strange because the crimes against tourists are so low (perhaps the regular robbery) and even more in the country side when there are actually a lot of foreigners living in the area because it offers a cooler weather than the rest of the country and has a vast of green scenery. 
I remember a native girl in my class saying that some indigenous groups are more protective of their areas than others and they have strange practices but they are kept in the low to the rest of the world. 
Others said that maybe they came across to some sketchy activities and were killed because of what they witnessed.
Some people suspect the tourist guide that was supposedly going with them they canceled with him but I can't remember why, locals also  advice them not to go alone and if I'm not mistaken the guide went into their room as well after they went missing, don't know why the owner of the place they were staying allowed this.
I personally don't know much of the area but I have gone sightseeing Chiriqui and other places around the country and the terrain can be very treacherous specially with our crazy weather where it can be sunny and the next minute is pouring, maybe one was injured and this added to the fact that they could have been lost is so scary.
I get chills just thinking about what could have happened to them any of this scenarios is terrifying üòî

text: I just watched someone else's video on this horrible case. I can't post the link from my phone. I think it was posted 4 months ago. He suggested it was the tour guide who was responsible. He said the 2 girls caught a taxi. The driver gave an inaccurate time for dropping them off. He was found drowned in shallow water a year later. He and the tour guide were 2 people who the girls supposedly told about their plans to go hiking. The video showed a review of the tour guide - from a woman who strongly recommended not to travel alone on his tour. She said he started touching her, and joked about cutting off her legs with his machete. The foot that was found had a clean cut, just like a machete would make. Also, the tour guide apparently has a coffee farm right where the girls were missing. AND he supposedly went to where the girls were staying, and conducted a search of their room, for 30 minutes, and he was alone in the room the whole time. What was he looking for? It goes to show, if the locals tell you it is unsafe to hike, listen to what they're telling you. I'm so sorry for what these young girls went through, and for their families having to live with this now, and without the answers and justice they deserve. I'm amazed that someone making a YouTube video can think to check out reviews for this tour guide, but the police did not. And I would be surprised if they, or the locals, don't know more than they are letting on. RIP Lisanne and Kris.

author: @iwikAeM

text:
I'm sceptical of the murder theories, although they're understandable, given past crimes involving young women hikers in foreign countries. I have myself been seriously lost in the woods twice, and once guided out a young woman lost in the woods at night while I was camping just off the Appalachian trail. Each time it was dramatic how fast disorientation and panic set in - it's the panic-fear that makes one automatically do the opposite of what one should do. It's not like your car's GPS stops working on a road trip. It's more like falling off a cruise ship and watching it disappear over the horizon. I can only infer that in the most serious cases, especially after days of food deprivation and chronic anxiety and stress, disorientation could become so severe that the two inexperienced girls in the Panama case would begin acting almost pathologically confused, while desperate hope may have led them to forego goodbye messages for the sake of attempts to reach local rescue until the batteries in their phones went dead and it was too late.

I've watched a couple of the better pieced-together videos and I found myself getting sceptical of the murder theories when I saw too much bias in that direction. For example, some of the "happy" photos early on in their hike were slightly distorted or the clouds seemed mis-timed from one snap to the next or the one girl was supposedly a little depressed or anxious looking, and to me all that seemed overly subjective and irrelevant to any criminal activity. The idea of any killers allowing their victims to keep taking photos is ridiculous, not just because it creates possible evidence but because abduction and murder (rape also) is about having complete power and control over someone.

Why would a killer and not the girls turn the phones on and off? Only the girls had any reason to do that repeatedly, and if they had the chance to do so around an abductor, they also would have had the chance to escape. The backpack could have been misplaced by the girls in their disoriented state until a villager found and took it, then returned it, dry, to the same (or a different) spot once they got wind of rescue efforts for the owner of the backpack and realized it might implicate them in more than just ‚Äúfinders, keepers.‚Äù

As for the photos in the camera, how would taking dozens of photos of the sky at night serve to mislead police? And the height-distorted photo of Lisanne? Digital photos occasionally are goofy like that (I have a rear-view pic of my motorcycle where the panniers look like two different sizes). The clouds at the trail overlook completely mismatching in photos taken seconds apart? Weird, but how does that suggest foul play, when the girls are posing normally? The deleted photo? A tech-savvy killer would only take the batteries out of the phones and throw everything in the river or bury it all, making deleting photos unnecessary and also increasing the mystery to the killer‚Äôs advantage. Anyways, why disguise a murder as an accident, when both possibilities (murder or losing their way) are going to be speculated about regardless? I can certainly see the girls using the camera flashes to attempt signalling toward airplane sounds and checking for hazards in their path (note the one photo of a dangerous drop down a rock). Furthermore, why would a killer force-march two victims miles through a jungle, only to kill them in the middle of nowhere? That makes no sense - killers aren't lazy, but what advantage would there be to the killer?

I think these girls just got hopelessly lost, and that leads me back to my own experiences of being lost in the woods - the more you try to guess your way out in a panicked and confused state of mind, the more lost you get. To me, the most important thing about this tragedy isn't how the girls died, but the decisions they made leading up to their disappearance. They'd worked hard as waitresses in the Netherlands to save for the trip and they were young, idealistic and eager, so it's understandable they'd be adventurous. But they'd already reached their goal of living in that small tropical town in Panama and they hadn't even seriously explored the town itself yet. They had a guided hike scheduled for the next day. What was the hurry to get into the jungle? Going to extremes is always a dangerous thing, and getting too adventurous too soon was going to an extreme. I think the girls were their own killers.

text:
In the disappearance of these two Dutch girls, there are two situations that I don't understand and I believe that need a more careful analysis:
1-If in the first two calls to the Dutch emergency number, they were already under the control of kidnappers, why didn't the criminals take the phones, the camera and all their belongings?

This doesn't make any sense! No offenders with murderous or sexual intentions would risk being photographed by their victims, or even risk the girls calling the police or leaving a message recorded on their cell phones for when they are found by the authorities.

2- Why don't you have any attempt to call 911 during the night?

What would be the worst moment for two girls from an urban environment, lost in the middle of a tropical jungle?
Do you agree with me that this worst moment would be to spend the night in the forest?! Exhausted, cold, with animals moving on the ground, animal movement in the dark forest, a plague of insects, rain spray, hunger, thirst and darkness everywhere. This would undoubtedly be the time when they would most try to connect to an emergency number, but they didn't.

Trying to explain these two situations, the best way to harmonize was as follows:
Lisanne and Kris decided on their own, to continue the trail past the viewpoint, when they realized they couldn't make it back before nightfall, or because they really got lost and disoriented, they decided to make the first two calls in the late afternoon of April 1st. . Without success, they must surely have screamed for help. They were certainly answered and rescued by someone who heard them both scream, or someone who somehow passed them on the trail. This would explain why the girls did not attempt to call an emergency number during the night, that is, they felt safe to be accompanied by someone they believed to be trustworthy and well intentioned.
After that, they certainly went with that someone, to some nearby property, where they continued to be deceived by lies that reassured them, but that at dawn and after a night's sleep, they always tried to make another emergency call, until the cell phone battery has discharged.
It was at that moment that this someone realized that they were totally incommunicado and certainly decided to attack and take their belongings that were all inside the backpack.
From then on, all the evil that befell the girls began.

In my opinion, between the moment the last cell phone ran out of charge and the dawn of the 8th, Kris Kremers was killed, so in the photos taken on the 8th, only the hair of a lifeless body of Kris appears, trying to simulate a disappearance, with them lost in the night trying to signal their position in the woods and kris dead in Lisanne's arms (who doesn't appear in the photos) as it's the killer planting false evidence, not Lisanne!

As the pieces of Lisanne Froon's skin were found in mid-June, in an initial state of decomposition, this shows that Lisanne was killed in early June and was under the control of this someone who killed her, for about 60 days. She was the last to die.

Note 1: Seeing the holes in Kris' Jeans, it shows that her dead body was dragged a short distance, where it was thrown. That is, this may indicate that the place where Kris and Lisanne were killed and the bodies were subjected to a chemical treatment for dismemberment and then concealment, are very close to each other, and may be in the vicinity of this property where they felt "safe" .

Note 2: The photo of Kris' hair at night, may not have been photographed in the forest, but in a closed and dark environment.

Note 3: Kris' boot found, was it clean and without any remains inside? No animal in the forest, would be interested in carrying a leather boot in her mouth! It's not food! That's how the animals would see this boot, any object, they would have smelled it and gone. That boot was taken to the forest by the killer.

Note 4: The police know of more evidence, maybe even the photo that was deleted. At the very least, they want to make some strategic use.

Conclusion: Kris Kremers and Lisanne Froon, were held captive in an environment they thought was safe, were killed, stripped naked, with the bodies being dismembered by some chemical process as yet unknown. Some dismembered parts, along with the girls' boots, clothes and backpack with all the girls' belongings, were deliberately abandoned along the straight-line trail to create false leads and simulate that the girls died of hunger and thirst after getting lost in the deep in the forest.

The death of these innocent girls touched me a lot! This is my small contribution to unravel their deaths and thus lead to a punishment, the possible murderer and the possible collaborators.

Fortaleza-CE, Brazil.

I very much hope that Jesus Christ will comfort Kris and Lisanne's parents.

text:
Such a waste of life! Very sad ending to two lovely girls that had their whole life ahead of them.

Since watching this have been reading up and watching more about this case.

I was caught between them being "lost" then "abducted" based on everything presented, but two things stood out for me me: 1) The photo of the branches with red or orange pieces of plastic tied to them and what looks like metal coloured bubble gum wrappers on the rock, and 2) The backpack and two bras.

I don't think they were abducted at all.

The wrappers I reckon were meant to reflect the sun and all of it was to gain the attention perhaps of a plane, helicopter or someone with binoculars. The mirror too.

As for the backpack being miles away and in perfect condition means it was found weeks before and likely near the bodies - perhaps the bras were removed to be kept. No report made.

It seems there were tribe(s) living in the jungle so this could have been a tribal member that did it - like from the Ngabe Bugle. I was going to say I'm not too sure about cannibalism until I read that last year (2020) there was an incident of it with a religious sect, however, I think that is not their case in hindsight.

I think someone came across their bodies and took the bag and bras only didn't report it. And as they made local and worldwide headlines the bag was placed somewhere to be found only nowhere were they actually died and maybe the bodies were brought closer so as to also be discovered.

text:
All it takes is 50 feet in the wrong direction before the jungle swallows you up. You have to make a life-or-death guess at the exact same time you realize what's happening and start to panic. I got lost like that in a Florida state forest following a false trail for 20 minutes. I miraculously picked the right direction and found an old logging/ranger road after a couple hours. But if I had gone with my first instinct, I could have easily vanished. You are either saving yourself or killing yourself, and you have no way to know which one you're doing. I still dream about it 20 years later. It's a special type of horror.

ALSO, I think the missing photo is explained by a good Samaritan. The image before the missing file is Kris's hair. I think Kris fell and injured herself badly, possibly even dying. Lisanne was trying to triage her in the dark by taking pictures. Because of her injury or otherwise grim appearance, the deleted image was shocking. text:
It's interesting that the parents said ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt get lost on the path‚Äù. Videos from youtuber Romain C who walked the whole path and documented it show a different reality. It definitely doesn‚Äôt look clear and easy. Beyond the Mirador, especially after the first spring, the terrain is difficult and there are several animal paths (from cattle) that branch off from the trail. Finding the way on the paddocks also proved very difficult by other hikers who documented their journey. ¬†

The backpack was not found in ‚Äúperfect condition‚Äù. It was scratched and miscolored with holes and sand in it. One of the phones was severely water damaged. One reason why the contents weren‚Äôt more damaged from travel along the river could be that it was fairly light. Newtons law says two objects that collide exert the same force on each other. The rocks that the backpack undoubtedly bumped up against only exerted a minimal force on it, because of its relatively light weight. 

From the report: 
‚ÄúThe backpack was found in good general condition, but is dirty and contains several damages, which are listed below.
The attachment of one of the straps is partly loose.
The plastic closures contain deep scratches
The textile parts show signs of discoloration in various places.
A rectangular piece of the fabric (approx. 30√ó15 mm) at the top right corner is missing. The edges of this damage are straight; they contain frayed fabric ends.
A straight tear immediately adjacent to damage 4.
This damage is approximately 10 mm long and contains straight fabric ends on one side and on the other side the fabric ends are frayed. The fabric is discolored near this damage (as described in damage 3)‚Äù

*The backpack contained a total of $88.30 USD, not $83.

* The backpack was brought to the local village of Alto Romero before it was handed over to police, thus the DNA found on it (3 samples out of 13 taken contained DNA) could be from the villagers that handled it. 

* ‚Äú77 attempts to call emergency services‚Äù. Not true, they tried 8 times.

text: My theory on the backpack Along the trails and mountains in this area are small villages of "Indians" (some would call them Native Americans). These are not the same as the "Anglo" Hispanics that are most of the Panamanian population. These people are distrustful of Anglos and generally want nothing to do with them other than the money to be made from picking coffee beans in the farms when they ripen. Otherwise, these are impoverished people who haven't advanced much in hundreds of years. I have noticed, however, that they enjoy the obvious functions of a backpack and many wear them, including the children, because much of their transportation is on foot. I would not be surprised if one of them saw the girls' backpack after their disappearance and took it believing it was a freebie. They are largely insular people and cut off from civilization so they might not have even been aware that the Anglos were searching for the two girls. However, once they were told, a likely response would be to re-pack it and leave it where it could be found, rather than alerting authorities who might suspect them of kidnapping or killing the girls. This would explain how the backpack appeared where searchers had already looked. This would explain the fingerprints on the backpacks that were not the girls. Since they keep to themselves, it's unlikely police would have the fingerprints or DNA on file of the Indians to determine whose they were.

text: No one did this to them. These 2 girls caused their own deaths. They did a jungle trek spontaneously without a plan, did not wear appropriate clothing, did not bring enough water and food. Made a fatal decision to continue hiking past the summit. Called for help when they got caught in the jungle at dusk and had to stay there overnight but made a fatal decision to continue walking the next morning when fog hit and walked further and further away. One of them got injured, Kris broke her pelvis fell into a ravine and her best friend went after her but injured her foot on the way down. They couldn't escape and died of hunger, hypothermia, shock. Their dead bodies got swept by flash floods. If they had just stayed at the spot of their first call for help they would have been found the next day or 2 days later. Don't blame this on any cartel or indigenous people. Their multiple poor decision making proved fatal. They didn't respect the jungle and it's dangers.

text: Killed by a jaguar. There are regional governmental conservation efforts to protect the jaguar. Any official autopsy would tend to block jaguar predation as a cause. One of the last photos taken has been forensically modified to help brighten the picture. You can see a large cat. Leaving this picture on the phone was a fortunate mistake on the part of the first agency to view the photos. Any clear pictures of a jaguar would have been erased, before it was released to the public. The girl was smart to create as much of a reflective surface as possible to temporarily flash-blind the jaguar. From the summit point, one of the young women saw how easy it would be to travel along the river all the way to the north coast, rather than turn around. The ginger girl, in one of the later pictures, was really uncomfortable with the idea of following the riverbank. A jaguar's main hunting area is the riverbank. Jaguars have one of the highest bite strengths of any animal. When a cat chews bone, it grinds it into a paste. The only bones left with mountain lion attacks tend to be the flesh they couldn‚Äôt get out of the footwear.

text: The local dog did come back before the girls but the host family was not alarmed nor did they contact the family... the family was not alarmed yet at this point either. It was actual Tour guide Feliciano that came to their home spoke with Mirium the host family den mother if you will and told her the girls where 90minutes late for the tour they booked that day, so he says. He then got the keys to their rooms since they where on a separate section from her own home and went into there room with out Miriam to look around. He then waited most reports say about 4 hours to then notify the authorities who then notified the family. Miriam the host family originally was not concerned until Feliciano showed up. He also found Lisanns shoe and foot bones, along with Krises well preserved shorts. that she must have some how taken off while "lost" in the jungle. Because if she died or was dying while in the shorts even in let's say level ten rapids there still would have been stains and DNA left from the shorts sliding of the decomposing body. However since there was no DNA the investigators surmise they where take off prior to anything happening to her body hence the lack of any decomposition DNA staining blood discoloring etc.  But thank God their tour guide was so concerned and dedicated to involving himself on some random girls who no showed his tour and lucky break finding the broken foot with fractures miles away from the other remains this guy must be like a super hero... alerting everyone and finding all the missing evidence. I am avid hiker and even when finding bones in the desert infested with coyotes--even among coyote skulls NOT ONCE have a seen any bones with chew marks. But to clean off a skull or bones such as big horn sheep the only way to do it is leave it out or bury it in leaves and such and forget it for a month. The various bugs will for a fact even get into the tiny sinuses and passages and eat everything even tendons and disks between vertabrae which would make the bones more easily fall apart during the flash floods. lost people found eventually if in or near water OFTEN are missing their heads. another video the best--they even brought in expert retired life long finding people and bodies and he made it clear what he saw is EXACTLY how they are found. yet everyone visualizes lions and coyotes ripping them apart--never bacteria and other tiny flesh eating things since they insulate the public from it. The first distress and almost certain injury from their many falls HAPPENED FAST. Chris certainly was the first to finally succumb and BOTH certainly had various falls of all types. Back of chris head with flash was likely to try to inspect an injury-THEN it became desperate. why was photo deleted and bras tucked away they likely were wet and YES in desperation they likely huddled naked in the cold. perhaps delirious perhaps one of the desperation photos had nudity in it? who knows. shorts on the rock? perhaps not skinny dipping Chris could have been already dead and they were left as another marker. They simply got disoriented and possibly thought they were heading back towards the town. absolutely falling injuries--note they did not really travel that far.

text:
No offence to the people of Panama, but the country isn't exactly famous for its great public safety and its best crime rate... 
No doubt there was a 3rd or even 4th (5th...) person with them for a period of time.
The investigation must have been sluggish and ineffective because a) incompetence of the local forensic department; b) Panama is also known for its poverty, so tourism is something the nation can monetize from - no way they'd admit that 2 young women were abducted&murdered while being on a hike on one of Panama's most popular trails; c) a&b combined.

The backpack was found dry and in a perfect condition after so many days because someone placed it there after having kept it indoors during the first few days.
NO WAY the girls just left the trail for fun and randomly "fell off" of the riverbank.
To that end, I cannot imagine myself as a young woman going on a hike with my girl friend in a foreign country where the crime rate is awfully high and gang activity is so common that even I am aware of it, thousands of kilometers away from Panama, in mid-Europe. It's common knowledge.
I dont care how "popular" the trail with tourists - just NO. No hikes in secluded areas in such countries; or without two guys, appropriate amounts of supplies and a carefully planned  what-to-do scenario in case of emergency . Paranoid? Maybe. Oh, wait. Watch the video again and tell me i am "paranoid". üò∂üôÑ
Poor girls and their families. ‚ù§üåπüò¢üò¢

text:
I think if the girls researched this hike and knew a waterfall was close, I can absolutely see them being at the volcano at (1:30pm I believe was the time on the pic) and saying the waterfall is so close, let‚Äôs give it a try. Knowing their time and being so intelligent talking themselves into a short cut or faster route- I‚Äôve been there hiking it‚Äôs late/ your tired & hungry, outta water, it‚Äôs so tempting to cut out parts of the trail. It‚Äôs not fair to say they‚Äôre too smart to leave the trail. 
The deleted photo could have been a shot of partial dressed or if they‚Äôre taking pics for orientation maybe they aimed it the wrong way and deleted so they wouldn‚Äôt become confused- lots of easy explanation.   
If one girl  slipped into the river canon I could see the other following to stay together. Also old tip if lost in the forest is to follow a river, so willing climb down into, it may even look easier then in a dense jungle- just seeing the sky would be uplifting. Those girls could‚Äôve walked that river for 2 weeks or sat and waited for rescue becoming weaker by the day. If they drank the water, water born illness could have made them extremely dehydrated. Now roll an ankle or fall or hit your head. One girl dies along the way, surviving one would continue until she couldn‚Äôt. Broken bones can be explained by large predator animals or floating down the river until it gets stuck somewhere. Surviving girl probably sat her backpack somewhere safe and dry to protect the phones and camera. Wrong pins can be explained by dehydration or trying to remember her friends PIN
The murderer theory is juicy and tantalizing but no evidence thanks to a poorly run investigation. 
The fact they tried emergency services that first day tells me they knew they were lost. A murderer isn‚Äôt gonna let them have their phones and call for help
Tragic all the way around. I‚Äôm so sorry for the girls and their family.

1. Bones: they were clean without flesh on it. No teeth bruise, scars on them. I can say it is bcos  the cannibal who skinned them and dismembered the body, had experience in butchering. (Nearly 50 gals and few men were disappeared b4) remember a clean butcher.
2. Night photos: i suppose they werent taken by kris or lisanne. They were surely photographed by tribes bcos we can note the way they were taken. Some1 who doesn't know how to handle camera. Kris' hair image must have  been taken after the scalp peeling.
3.backpack: after days it was found to us. Who will throw away a 83dollar.. A man eating people and living in caves/hideouts will definitely not need money. 
Then, kris' bones were found gathered in a place along with other men bones. This tells they dispose bones just like we throw trash in the can.
Also, lisa foot and fingers were found somewhere.. They were not fleshy We know. 
I found these when i glanced. If druglords or smugglers were involved, they would have not left bodies unburied or burnt.
